In an isothermal process, the temperature remains constant, while in an isochoric process, the volume remains constant.
The transition from B to C is represented by a vertical line in the P-V diagram, indicating no change in volume.
During an isochoric process, any change in pressure is directly related to a change in temperature according to the ideal gas law.
Since the volume is constant, any increase in pressure implies an increase in temperature, and any decrease in pressure implies a decrease in temperature.
Moving from B to C in the P-V diagram shows a decrease in pressure.
Since the volume is constant and the pressure decreases, the temperature must also decrease.
The intensity of thermal motion of gas molecules is directly related to the temperature of the gas.
Higher temperatures correspond to more intense thermal motion, while lower temperatures correspond to less intense thermal motion.
